awd_titl_txt: Type I: Iowa State University I-Corps Site: Driving Innovation through Entrepreneurial Talent
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, from Iowa State University (ISU), creates an I-Corps Site at this institution. 

NSF Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors.

The primary goal of the ISU Site is to embed a strong and pervasive culture of entrepreneurship and innovation across the entire campus community. With a rigorous and experiential program of study, led by experts, this Site interfaces with other innovation Sites in the Midwest and, within five years, is expected to propel the university towards reaching its full potential in terms of creating new ventures. This goal is being accomplished via a new entrepreneurial ecosystem that effectively integrates several key components including a continuum of entrepreneurship options, mentors, funding networks and assistance, Angel investors, a "Startup Factory" program and space in a new Startup Factory Building. 

Expectations are that the ISU Site is energizing solutions to grand challenges - such as food production to serve a growing global population - that require innovative thinking and creativity in agriculture, engineering and other disciplines. ISU, a land grant institution steeped in traditions of agriculture, contributes a record of entrepreneurial contributions reflecting its strengths in engineering, bio-renewables, materials science and agriculture. In the long term, the I-Corps site will generate a new body of academics, holistically trained as scientists-technologists-entrepreneurs, equipped with knowledge and skills to galvanize transformative new solutions to vexing agricultural and other global problems that will ensure the robustness and sustainability of the food and energy supply chain. Association with other agricultural and engineering schools in the Midwest enhances the knowledge base and creates a virtual network of innovators and entrepreneurs driving the economy of the entire Midwest region. 

Through partnership with the Iowa Economic Development Authority (IEDA), the Iowa Innovation Council and the Iowa Innovation Corporation (I-ICorp), novice entrepreneurs from the ISU innovation ecosystem connect with the broader network of venture capitalists and business leaders in the state; through practical experiential learning modules, cohorts collaborate with a diversity of successful real-world entrepreneurial businesses (bioscience, information technology, bioenergy etc.) in the Research Park as well as the more mature companies (Pioneer-DuPont, Monsanto and John Deere) that drive the economic engine of the state; and, the Site training program incorporates respect for and inclusiveness of all forms of diversity in the innovation economy.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

por.por_cntn:
Investment in fundamental research by the US federal government has been credited with fueling the United States’ role as a leader in creating ground-breaking innovations and launching new industries. In this context, Iowa State University of Science and Technology (ISU) has been one of the leaders of the research-based innovation revolution and has a rich history of turning research discoveries into enduring products and companies.  

As an NSF I-Corps Site, our mission is to support innovation at ISU through practical, hands-on learning experiences for faculty, students and post-docs, by helping them to explore and learn how to transform ground-breaking science and engineering discoveries into solutions to real world problems. Our 5-week program used the flipped classroom, team teaching “Lean LaunchPad” approach developed by Steve Blank.  The program focused on customer discovery and business concepts towards the transitioning of ideas, devices, processes, or intellectual activities into the marketplace. The modules addressed the following:

  • How is the idea going to solve a problem (“pain”) or add value (“gain”)?
  • Who are the potential customers and stakeholders?
  • How to conduct interviews with potential customers (“customer discovery”) without revealing your “secret sauce”
  • Is there commercial potential?
  • Is your solution better than the competition?

Over the course of five years, teams consisting of an academic lead (typically a faculty member or a senior researcher), an entrepreneurial lead (graduate students or post-doc) and an optional mentor (a subject-matter expert in the area or someone with experience and knowledge to provide guidance and network connections), drawn from a wide array of STEM disciplines participated in the program. Creative project ideas focused on translating discoveries reflecting ISU’s strengths in fields such as engineering, computational sciences, data analytics, biotechnology, biology, chemistry, plant sciences, materials science, agriculture, food and nutrition, veterinary medicine and health sciences. At each session, each team presented their customer discovery findings to the teaching team and the rest of the cohort for discussion and critique.

I-Corps successes since inception in September 2017 to the end date of August 31, 2022, can be briefly summarized as follows:

  • More than 120 teams comprising 300 students, postdocs, faculty and staff representing all colleges have participated
  • 14 teams have completed or been accepted into the competitive National I-Corps Teams program
  • More than $8 million in additional funding has been generated in commercialization grants and investment funding
  • 20 new companies launched 

Some examples of the benefits of our I-Corps program are illustrated in these links (I-Corps Proves a Training Ground for Success, From Industry to ... (google.com); I-Corps Experience Helped Chart 3D Health Solutions' Path to ... (google.com);  Nigel Reuel research group featured in look at ISU I-Corps program ... (google.com); Innovation Corps at Iowa State: Helping researchers turn ideas into ... (google.com); Iowa State's I-Corps Program holds up Alipour as success story ... (google.com); Researcher designs better maternity garments, launches company ... (google.com)

Our program included an additional “cultural competency” training module to help participants understand the influence of cultural differences, enhance their ability to form and work in diverse teams, increase their knowledge in fair and unbiased practices for their companies and incorporate respect for and inclusiveness of all forms of diversity in the innovation economy. This class was spearheaded by two highly accomplished campus leaders, Dr. Theressa Cooper, Assistant Dean of Diversity, College of Agriculture and Life Sciences, and Dr. Susan Lamont, Equity Advisor, College of Agriculture and Life Sciences, and C.F. Curtiss Distinguished Professor.

To continue to support a culture of entrepreneurship and innovation rooted in fundamental research, ISU also hosted the annual meeting of The Midwest Engineering Entrepreneurship Network (MEEN) in 2019. MEEN is an organization of about 30 universities and research institutions that supports and develops best practices for entrepreneurship through education and collaboration and expanding the innovator network in the Midwest.

 


Last Modified: 11/08/2022
Modified by: Aragula Rao
